Title: Senior Investigative Reporter
Description:
Welcome. We are The Markup (https://themarkup.org/) -- a brand new nonpartisan, nonprofit journalism organization in New York City. We're hiring! Our mission is to investigate and illuminate the societal effects of new technologies. With little accountability or oversight, technology is affecting who we vote for, how we raise our kids, who is able to get housing, jobs, healthcare and a comfortable life. We will investigate these impacts, with the goal of holding the powerful to account, raising the cost of bad behavior, and spurring reforms. We begin publishing in 2019. The Markup is looking for experienced Investigative Reporters who have also demonstrated strong data skills to lead investigative projects. The Markup is committed to building a team that includes a wide variety of backgrounds and perspectives, and an organizational culture that is reader-centered, inventive, rigorous, and courageous. A collaborative team-based approach is core for us: we won't tolerate jerks. We aim to be a place where a diverse mix of dedicated people will want to come, to stay, and do their best work. We do not discriminate on the basis of race, color, religion, age, sexual orientation, gender identity, gender expression, marital status, country of origin, citizenship, ancestry, physical or mental disability, or veteran status. About the position At The Markup, investigations are the heart of what we do. We are seeking an inventive, rigorous and collaborative Senior Investigative Reporter who can lead investigations, be comfortable with data and spreadsheets, and write compelling articles based on our findings.  Our approach to investigative journalism is guided by the scientific method. We develop hypotheses and assemble data —through crowdsourcing, FOIAs, and automated data collection— to test our theories.  Senior Investigative Reporters will often work alongside a Data Journalist to conduct investigations. Together they will develop a hypothesis and strategize about data collection techniques. The Senior Investigative Reporter will develop the necessary domain expertise in the topic area, find interesting anecdotes to illustrate the findings and conceive and shape the narrative of the article.  This position will report to the Editor-in-Chief.  Responsibilities Senior Investigative Reporters will be responsible for working closely with Data Journalists, producing and writing several investigations per quarter, as well as explanatory articles.  Investigative Journalism is a team sport. The Markup’s Senior Investigative Reporters will work closely with Investigative Data Journalists to develop hypotheses, collect data and develop findings. You will also work with other parts of the newsroom to explain and promote your findings and with our editorial partners outside the newsroom.  You will also be the custodian of your own digital security. We will provide the tools, but you will need to use two-factor authentication, password managers, encryption and other tools and tactics that can help us protect our work and our sources.  

Because our team- and data-based approach to journalism is new, there won’t be many people who have done it before. So don’t worry if you haven’t done the exact type of data journalism we plan to practice. The skills we are looking for are: You have strong data judgement and can see a story in a dataset.  You know how to spot a story. You have a minimum of five years of experience as an investigative journalist. You know proven impact. You have worked on successful investigations that have led to real world change. You are a fast, clean writer. You have spent a minimum of five years writing news articles on a deadline. You are passionate about accuracy. You are willing to go the extra mile to check even facts that seem obvious. You are skilled at cultivating relationships with sources and are diligent about protecting them.  You are data literate. You can use Excel (maybe you are not an expert, but are willing to learn) and committed to learning other technical skills on the job as needed. You enjoy learning and are flexible. This is a new form of journalism and we’ll all be learning how to do it together. Experience covering the technology industry is a plus, but not a requirement.

Title: WAMU Spring 2019 Internship Program
Description: WAMU Spring 2019 Internship Program   Working alongside the professional staff of WAMU, interns contribute to the day-to-day operations of the station. To be eligible for an internship at WAMU 88.5, you must be 18 or older. You must also be authorized to work in the United States. Interns are expected to work at least 20 hours per week. All interns are paid $15 per hour. The amount received during the internship is based on hours per week and the length of the internship period. An intern who is not an American University student can expect to work about 25 hours per week on average. American University student interns can work a maximum of 20 hours per week. Schedules will be determined once an offer is made. Academic credit can also be received for an internship. We explore the most compelling and relevant DCissues emerging in policy, politics, technology, sports, pop culture, and humor—with an emphasis on what connects us and what keeps us apart. Our goal is to act as a national mirror—helping America look at itself and find time to ask itself what it wants to be. The live show airs Monday–Friday from 10 a.m.–12 p.m. EST. We produce a daily show for on-demand audiences, as well as a shorter daily podcast. Interns can expect a hands-on experience. From day one, they will contribute to the production of the program and work alongside the 1A team. They will produce on-air and online stories, conduct research, pitch stories, and help live-stream certain shows. Our interest in you should be matched by your interest in us. You will be among those committed to upholding the highest standards of radio and online journalism. Key responsibilities:  Pitch story ideas Share content online Attend the daily editorial meeting Produce on-air and online stories Conduct research for stories Support the administrative and tech needs of the show Write up interviews  Qualifications:  Creative thinker Ability to report and tell many kinds of stories Ability to juggle multiple tasks with accuracy and efficiency and work well with all staff Excellent research skills Ability to work under deadline pressure Strong written and oral communication skills  Preferred skills:  Some reporting and broadcast experience Knowledge of WAMU and NPR programming Digital media skills        DCist Internship Description and Requirements   DCist aims to be the homepage of the District—publishing breaking local news, feature stories, tales of local curiosities, event guides, and other useful information for a large audience. Our tone is both playful and authoritative; we know and care about the city, and hope that you do, too. We're looking for an energetic, creative journalist who is excited about digging into the city’s stories in any of our coverage areas: news (including local politics, transportation, inequality, housing, and other beats), arts, and food. We’re a small team, and interns will participate in nearly all aspects of what we do every day.     Key responsibilities:  Developing story ideas Reporting and writing Conducting research Posting on DCist’s social media channels and contributing to our newsletter  Qualifications:  Interest in local news, and D.C. specifically Ability to work under quick deadlines Prior journalism experience or coursework  Preferred skills:  Photography, video, data journalism, graphic design, or other digital media skills        The Kojo Nnamdi Show Internship Description and Requirements   The Kojo Nnamdi Show is produced by WAMU. The show is a live local talk program that highlights local news, political issues and social trends of the day and includes listener’s calls, emails and tweets. The show airs Monday through Thursday from noon to 1 p.m. EST. On Friday, The Politics Hour airs from noon to 1 p.m. EST with resident analyst Tom Sherwood. The program connects the dots between events happening in Washington, D.C., and the state houses in Annapolis, Maryland, and Richmond, Virginia. Interns support all editorial aspects of the program. They conduct research on show topics, craft questions that are folded into host scripts, pitch story ideas, help with phone screening and live events. We're looking for creative people who are passionate about learning more about the Washington region through a local lens, and what it means to do local journalism. Our ideal candidate is curious about using a talk format to engage a local audience with captivating stories. Key responsibilities:  Conduct research on show topics Craft questions Attend daily editorial meeting Help with phone screening Pitch story ideas Support the administrative needs of the show  Qualifications:  Strong written and oral skills Well-read with abroad interests in literature, politics, sciences, arts, and entertainment Resourceful and motivated Excellent research skills Ability to respond to feedback and editorial direction  Preferred skills:  Some reporting and broadcast experience Knowledge of WAMU and NPR programming Digital media skills Audio editing skills        WAMU 88.5 Newsroom Internship Description and Requirements   The WAMU 88.5 news team is seeking aspiring journalists and college or graduate students with a keen interest in local news in the Washington region to work as paid interns in our local public media newsroom. As a growing multiplatform newsroom in a fast-changing place, we cover issues ranging from transportation and the arts to power and influence and education. Bachelors’ degree in finance or accounting, or equivalent experience

Working knowledge of Microsoft Excel, Word and Power Point. Access is a plus.

Excellent communication and interpersonal skills.

Title: Spring Intern: Open Source Policy Center
Description:
InternshipOverview
The Open Source Policy Center (OSPC) is making policy analysis more transparent, trustworthy, and collaborative. We incubate and contribute to open-source projects that build tools for economic policy analysis. Our focus for the last five years has been incubating cutting-edge economic models (and user interfaces for those models) for analyzing tax and benefit programs. Our user list includes Democratic and Republican presidential administrations, congressional offices, and presidential campaigns, as well as journalists, students, members of the open source community around the country, and the general public. To learn more about OSPC, please visit our website: www.ospc.org.

OSPC is looking to hire an intern with the following qualifications:
Programming experience (Preferably, but not necessarily, with Python)
General knowledge of econometrics, statistics, and working with data
Strong interest in public policy and open science, open data, or open source software generally
A desire to learn intrapreneurship and operations inside a leading institution like AEI

As an intern for OSPC, you will be a contributor to open-source projects like TaxData and Tax-Calculator. You will also provide general research assistance to other OSPC team members. You can expect to gain experience with web development and solving data analytics, engineering, and modeling problems within the context of public policy.

If you would like to share any software projects you have completed in the past or are working on now, please include your GitHub handle in your resume or cover letter (optional).

About AEI Internships
AEI internships offer a unique opportunity for undergraduates, graduate students, and recent graduates to gain experience in research, writing, business, and communications at one of the nation’s leading think tanks. Competitive candidates for these internships will generally possess a 3.4 GPA from a top ranking college or university.
AEI internships last a minimum of 10 weeks and interns are required to work 20-40 hours per week. AEI internships are unpaid; however, interns receive complimentary breakfast and lunch each day and a monthly transportation stipend to assist with commuting costs.

Title: Director, Career Development
Description:
Job Information
Job Summary:
The Director of Career Development is a senior member of the IOP’s team and is charged with creating and promoting programs, internships and career opportunities across a broad array of political and public service sectors that help University of Chicago students gain exposure to these fields and advance their professional goals. He/she plays a key role in the operation of these and other IOP programs and represents the IOP to a broad range of diverse constituencies on campus and off.
At the heart of these efforts is the IOP’s acclaimed student internship program, featuring paid, substantive opportunities for hundreds of undergraduate and graduate students every academic year and summer. The Director of Career Development is charged with leading all such programs, recruiting employer partners domestically and internationally, and managing relationships with these 300+ employer partners. He/she collaborates with various University offices and divisions to ensure such opportunities are advertised to students through University systems and that applications are managed in a clear and transparent manner. He/she also oversees and administers the Charles H. Percy Summer in Washington program, which provides a comprehensive set of panels, programs, speakers, and social events for the 80+ UChicago IOP interns working in Washington, DC every summer.

In addition, the Director of Career Development leads other IOP efforts year-round to expand student career knowledge, career networks and professional skill sets. The Director provides one-on-one career advising to University undergraduate and graduate students, as well as manages a series of career development workshops featuring practitioners from a variety of public service fields. The Director plans and oversees the annual career development trip to Washington, DC, in which students attend site visits and meetings with government officials, policymakers, journalists, and advocates. He/she also manages the IOP’s Alumni Engagement initiative.

The Director of Career Development reports to the IOP’s Executive Director and manages a Program Coordinator and the Career Development intern. He/she works closely with other IOP program areas on cross-programmatic initiatives and projects. The Director collaborates with a wide array of University departments and divisions, including the University’s Office of Career Advancement. In addition, the Director is responsible for planning and managing the entire internship program budget, as well as writing and preparing annual reports for internship program funders.
